race.name: Dirty Pecan
race.tagline: Red clay tunnels and pecan orchards through Florida's panhandle backcountry.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through FL countryside. Minimal elevation with FL scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional FL event. Flat terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Dirty Pecan is a regional event in Florida‚Äîflat terrain with minimal elevation. The FL scenery is nice, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Florida provides good access.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional FL gravel race with flat terrain. Worth it for FL/Southeast cyclists. Not a destination race for national travelers.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in FL/Southeast and want a local event‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're from out of region‚Äîthere are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For similar regional events: other FL gravel races. For more elevation: GA/NC gravel races.

logistics.food: FL has full dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.camping: Camping Culture:** Dry camping available for $40 for 2 nights with "A huge camp fire awaits you hardy campers!" at the Jefferson

non_negotiables.why: FL flat terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: The event's unsupported nature is clearly stated: 'there is NO support, NO sag stops, NOR support vehicles. The course will NOT be marked.' Registration costs just $25 with free parking and port-o-lets at the UF extension service start area. However, riders need 40mm+ tires despite website claims that 'skilled riders would do fine on 28 or 30 tires,' as K-Dogg's team discovered.

length.explanation: Multiple distance options from 40 to 200 miles let riders match ambition to fitness. K-Dogg warned his group early: 'I'm pretty sure this pace isn't sustainable for another 140 miles' after just 10 miles on the 150-mile route. Dave chose the 80-mile option knowing he'd be dropped by the century group, finding it 'perfectly fine.' Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As K-Dogg puts it: "The first 15ish miles was a bike race and of course my fellow Blackwater Gravel Grinders wanted to be near the front."

technicality.explanation: Red clay roads become 'sticky and criss crossed by washouts' when conditions deteriorate. K-Dogg described 12 miles of 'slippery, dead flat wet sand' where 'every stroke was an effort' and drafting was 'virtually useless.' Dave found the 2025 route was 'mostly packed sand' with occasional 'random red mud spots.' Less technical than The Mid South. As K-Dogg puts it: "The web site promised that conditions were superb and that skilled riders would 'do fine' on 28 or 30 tires but we knew better. Team Gravel Cyclist rocked 40mm wide tires and up."

elevation.explanation: North Florida's rolling terrain offers minimal climbing despite K-Dogg noting 'hills got longer and steeper' on red clay. One rider nearly bonked on 'one particularly long hill' with five miles to go in the 150-mile route. Dave's 2025 ride included 'scores of hills' in the final paved miles, but nothing approaching serious elevation. Flatter profile than Croatan Buck Fifty.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 83¬∞F and lows of 62¬∞F, with a 30% chance of rain on any given day. March conditions started 'chilly but beautiful' at 42 degrees in 2025, warming significantly by ride's end to 'good hard and hot' temperatures. The early-season timing provides ideal weather before Florida heat becomes oppressive, though riders face full sun between oak canopy sections. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Monticello, Florida sits in low-elevation North Florida with no altitude considerations whatsoever. Sea-level riding means no acclimatization needs or breathing challenges for any rider category. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: K-Dogg described 'mile after mile rolling up and down rusty red clay hills through countless bucolic mossy oak tunnels' with 'so much openness and so few people.' The unique red clay terrain through pecan orchards offers scenery unavailable elsewhere, though the unsupported format with no course marking adds navigation challenges.

prestige.explanation: The charity ride format supporting 4-H programs has raised nearly $200,000 over 10 years, doubling attendance to 400+ riders. However, the explicitly unsupported nature and $25 entry fee position this as a community fundraiser rather than a competitive event drawing serious racing talent.

race_quality.explanation: The completely unsupported format means 'YOU are 100% responsible for YOU, YOUR welfare, YOUR equipment, YOUR navigation, and YOUR own food and drink.' No course marking, aid stations, or support vehicles create a self-sufficient adventure rather than organized race infrastructure.

experience.explanation: Riders traverse Jefferson County, the 'Pecan Capital of the World,' through historic farmsteads so quiet 'you could hear a cotton boll drop.' K-Dogg noted breaking into 'green meadows and gorgeous historic farmsteads' with 'virtually no traffic' through the mossy oak tunnels.

community.explanation: Co-founder Betsy Barfield has built something drawing riders like Randy Honcik from North Carolina who appreciate 'the energy of the group' and 'beautiful pecan farms.' The Blackwater Gravel Grinders exemplify the welcoming atmosphere, inviting Dave for post-ride dinner and camping with 'theraguns, air legs, talk of the day's ride.'

field_depth.explanation: The charity ride attracts adventure-seekers rather than competitive fields, with riders explicitly told 'if you need a juice box and a hug every 20 miles, this is not the ride for you.' A crusty older rider's comment 'Goddamn cross bikes! I thought I could hold you guys off!' captures the casual racing spirit. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: At $25 registration, all proceeds support 4-H overnight camps developing 'important leadership skills' in local kids. The 2025 event alone donated nearly $30,000, with the 10-year total approaching $200,000. Multiple distance options and free parking maximize accessibility for the charitable cause.

expenses.explanation: The $25 registration fee is exceptionally low, but Monticello's limited lodging options create accommodation challenges. Riders need specialized equipment including 40mm+ tires and navigation devices for the unmarked, unsupported routes. The UF extension service venue provides free parking and basic facilities. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Dirty Pecan Gravel Ride - 150 Miles on Mountain Bikes
videos.description:
Very fun event and highly recommend giving it a go.  They offer multiple mileage options and the best dirt/clay roads in Florida and Georgia.

Info on the Dirty Pecan Event:  https://www.dirtypecan.com/

videos.curation_reason: Recent first-person ride-along covering the longest distance option with specific details about the event organization and local area.

videos.title: Dirty Pecan for 2018 ‚Äì Monticello, Florida, USA
videos.description:
Saturday, March 3, 2018 marked the latest edition of the Dirty Pecan, a free event (with donations and sponsors supporting Jefferson County 4-H) beginning and ending in Monticello, Florida. Riders chose between 60, 80, 100 or 150-mile routes featuring dirt, gravel and clay roads, and a wee little sandy spot here and there. This video is the viewpoint from JOM of the Gravel Cyclist crew, and his 100-mile ride.

Web: http://GravelCyclist.com
Facebook: http://facebook.com/GravelCyclist
Instagram - http://Instagram/GravelCyclist
Twitter - http://twitter.com/GravelCyclist
Vimeo - http://vimeo.com/GravelCyclist

videos.title: Dirty Pecan 100+ Mile Bike Ride - A Gravel Adventure 2025
videos.description:
What a ride! Jason and I took on the 100-mile route at the Dirty Pecan gravel event, and it was an absolute beast. üí• Rolling through some of the most scenic and rugged gravel roads in North Florida, we battled everything from deep sand to chunky gravel and endless miles of remote beauty.

üî• Ride Highlights:
‚úÖ 100 miles of unpaved adventure
‚úÖ Stunning rural Florida scenery üåæ
‚úÖ Challenging terrain ‚Äì sand, gravel, and climbs
‚úÖ Endurance, grit, and good times

This ride was all about pushing limits, soaking in the journey, and enjoying the ride with great company. If you love gravel riding, endurance challenges, and epic adventures, this one‚Äôs for you!

üìç Event Info: Dirty Pecan Official Website

üí¨ Drop a comment! Have you tackled the Dirty Pecan before? Thinking about doing it next year? Let‚Äôs talk gravel!

üîî Don‚Äôt forget to LIKE, COMMENT, & SUBSCRIBE for more epic cycling adventures! üöµ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Follow my journey!
üì∫ Subscribe: @lifeofv365
üì∏ Follow on Strava: https://www.strava.com/athletes/64042442
#GravelCycling #DirtyPecan #LifeOfV #CyclingAdventure #EnduranceRide #jasonsipple #ironsipple

videos.title: Dirty Pecan
videos.channel: No Feet on the Ground Cycling
videos.description:
2025 Dirty Pecan Gravel Ride ‚Äì The Ultimate Backroad Challenge! 

An unforgettable adventure at the Dirty Pecan Gravel Ride 2025! Took place in the scenic backroads of North Florida. This epic ride offers miles of remote, hard-packed gravel, stunning forest views, and a true test of endurance.

Location: Monticello, Florida
Distances: 30, 60, 100, and 150-mile routes
Terrain: Mixed gravel, dirt, and scenic rural roads

The Dirty Pecan is a must-ride event for every gravel grinder. Expect minimal traffic, friendly vibes, and a ride experience you won‚Äôt forget!

Don‚Äôt forget to like, comment, and subscribe for more gravel ride adventures!

#DirtyPecan #GravelCycling #GravelRide #BikeAdventure #CyclingLife

quotes.text: The surfaces of this event vary from hard-packed clay roads to gravel and once in a while a tricky sandy spot. This be one of these sandy spots of the route which always causes problems for those riding 40 millimeter wide tires or less.

What was unique about Monticello, the county that it is, is the only County in the entire State of Florida that does not have AT&T signal. The event director was saying how this area will always remain small and undeveloped for the most part because north of here is several historic plantations where the land owners have been paid to give up rights for further development.

key_challenges.name: Gum Swamp Road
key_challenges.description: This sandpit completely blew up the group and riders' legs. Causes problems for those riding 40 millimeter wide tires or less.

key_challenges.name: Decision Point
key_challenges.description: Critical choice between continuing 38 more miles for the 150-mile route or taking the easier 100-mile option straight ahead.

terrain_notes.text: Surfaces vary from hard-packed clay roads to gravel with tricky sandy spots that cause problems for riders on narrower tires.
The route goes through pecan orchards on beautiful tree-lined Kennedy roads with plenty of rolling hills.

gear_mentions.text: Sandy spots cause problems for those riding 40 millimeter wide tires or less. First event where rider officially used 650b wheels instead of keeping them just for training.

race_day_tips.text: Stick towards the front but avoid going into the red zone early. Plan to hang with the front group for at least 20 miles then shut it down to a sustainable pace.
Start early for longer distances - 150-mile riders started at 7am when it was 40 degrees with mist.

additional_quotes.text: All proceeds go to their local 4-H, and usually every year they give $20,000 but with a record 480 people signed up this year, they're trying to give $30,000.

They provide camping for RVs in one area, always put the RVs in a separate spot because of generators. They had a big bonfire and here's the area for tent campers - this is the quiet area so no generators allowed.
Jefferson County is the only county in the entire state of Florida that does not have AT&T cell signal.

rider_intel.search_text: The Dirty Pecan in Monticello, Florida offers multiple distance options from 60 to 200 miles, with most of the route extending into Georgia. The terrain varies from hard-packed clay roads to gravel with challenging sandy sections, particularly at Gum Swamp Road 15 miles from the finish, which riders describe as completely blowing up groups. The route features rolling hills through beautiful tree-lined Kennedy roads and pecan orchards. Sandy spots cause significant problems for riders on 40mm tires or less. The race starts early for longer distances, with 150-mile riders beginning at 7am in 40-degree weather. A critical decision point at mile 75 determines whether riders continue for 38 additional miles on the 150-mile route or take the easier 100-mile option. The event draws 480+ riders on various bikes including mountain bikes and fat bikes, with proceeds benefiting local 4-H programs. Camping is available with separate RV and tent areas.
